12.question: Explain the difference between classification and regression.
12.referenceAnswer: Classification and regression <Point1:1>differ in the type of output they predict<Point1:1>. <Point2:1>Classification predicts discrete labels (categories)<Point2:1>, whereas <Point3:1>regression predicts continuous quantities<Point3:1>.
12.studentAnswer: Regression predicts numerical outcomes, and classification predicts which category something belongs to.
12.feedback:
<Point1:1> *True* (The student correctly identifies that classification and regression differ in the type of output they predict.)
<Point2:1> *True* (The student correctly states that classification predicts discrete labels or categories.)
<Point3:1> *True* (The student correctly states that regression predicts continuous quantities.)

36.question: Define overfitting in machine learning.
36.referenceAnswer: <Point1:2>Overfitting occurs when a machine learning model learns the details and noise in the training data to an extent<Point1:2>.  <Point2:2>It negatively impacts the performance of the model on new data, making it less generalizable<Point2:2>.
36.studentAnswer: Overfitting is when your model learns too much from the training data, including the noises, so it doesn’t perform well on new data.
36.feedback:
<Point1:2> *True* (The student's definition correctly explains that overfitting occurs when a model learns the details and noise in the training data.)

<Point2:2> *True* (The student's explanation correctly states that overfitting negatively impacts the performance of the model on new data, making it less generalizable.)

60.question: Which is more important to you – model accuracy, or model performance?
60.referenceAnswer: Well, <Point1:1>it has everything to do with how model accuracy is only a subset of model performance, and at that, a sometimes misleading one<Point1:1>. <Point2:2>For example, if you wanted to detect fraud in a massive dataset with a sample of millions, a more accurate model would most likely predict no fraud at all if only a vast minority of cases were fraud<Point2:2>. <Point3:2>However, this would be useless for a predictive model - a model designed to find fraud that asserted there was no fraud at all! Questions like this help you demonstrate that you understand model accuracy isn’t the be-all and end-all of model performance.<Point3:2>
60.studentAnswer: Model performance encompasses accuracy, but it’s broader. In cases like fraud detection, an accurate model might just predict no fraud if fraud cases are few, which isn’t helpful. Thus, understanding that performance includes other factors is crucial.
60.feedback:
<Point1:1> *True* (The student correctly states that model accuracy is a subset of model performance and can be misleading.)
<Point2:2> *True* (The student provides an example that demonstrates the limitations of an accurate model in a large dataset with a small number of fraud cases.)
<Point3:2> *True* (The student acknowledges that understanding the broader aspects of model performance is crucial, including factors beyond accuracy.)

<Point1:1> *True* (The student correctly states that model accuracy is a subset of model performance.)
<Point2:2> *True* (The student provides an example that demonstrates the limitations of model accuracy in predicting fraud in a large dataset.)
<Point3:2> *True* (The student acknowledges that model accuracy is not the only factor in determining model performance.)

67.question: What evaluation approaches would you work to gauge the effectiveness of a machine learning model?

74.question: Can Logistic Regression be used for multiclass classification problems? If so, how?
74.referenceAnswer: <Point1:2>Yes<Point1:2>, <Point2:1>logistic regression can be used for multiclass classification through methods<Point2:1> such as <Point3:1>the one-vs-rest (OvR) and the multinomial (softmax) approach<Point3:1>.
74.studentAnswer: Indeed, logistic regression is quite versatile when it comes to handling multiclass classification tasks. Unlike binary classification, where it predicts between two classes, logistic regression for multiclass problems uses various strategies to extend its application. For instance, one approach is the one-vs-rest method, where it creates separate models for each class against the rest, essentially turning the problem into multiple binary classifications. Another effective method is the multinomial approach, often implemented with softmax regression, which directly models the probabilities of each class. These techniques ensure logistic regression can effectively tackle multiclass scenarios, offering flexibility depending on the problem's complexity and data distribution.
74.feedback:
<Point1:2> True (The student correctly answered that logistic regression can be used for multiclass classification.)

<Point2:1> True (The student mentioned that logistic regression can be used for multiclass classification through methods.)

<Point3:1> True (The student correctly mentioned the one-vs-rest (OvR) and the multinomial (softmax) approach as methods for using logistic regression in multiclass classification.)
